data.title: How Sir Arthur Conan Doyle’s student days at Edinburgh University brought Sherlock Holmes to life
data.meta_description: One of Conan Doyle's lecturers impressed his students his remarkable powers of deduction
data.text:
The Scottish author Sir Arthur Conan Doyle was born in Edinburgh on 22 May 1859. A prolific writer, Conan Doyle is best-known as the creator of Sherlock Holmes.

Conan Doyle starting writing short stories while studying for his degree in medicine at the University of Edinburgh and these years as a student provided the bedrock for his most famous creation.

Fed up with traditional literary detectives who solved crimes through intuition alone, Conan Doyle wanted a scientific, rational hero.

He found it in his sharp-witted and perceptive lecturer, Dr Joseph Bell – a man who regularly impressed his students with remarkable powers of deduction based on solid scientific principles.

The author also, allegedly, found Sherlock’s trusty sidekick, Dr Watson, among Bell’s acquaintances in the form of a Dundee osteopath.

First appearing in A Study in Scarlet in 1887, the adventures of Holmes and Dr John Watson became wildly successful. Conan Doyle was less enamoured with his creation and in 1893 he did the unthinkable; in his tale The Final Problem he killed Holmes off at the Reichenbach Falls. Public outcry led to the return of Holmes in 1901 in The Hound of the Baskervilles.

Arthur Conan Doyle died in 1930. Celebrated as an author, during his lifetime he had been:-
